From: "Jason Rogers" <jacaetevha@...>


>  5. etc. (someone else chime in)

Okay, I don't know what level of testing/QA experience people on this list
have, but I assume most members of the list are developers with little real
experience. Testing and QA are a somewhat different mindset after all. So
excuse me if I come off as somewhat pedantic.

First, you can indeed do "too much testing" - or rather you can test
ineffectively and inefficiently. For example, if you have a method that
takes three integer arguments, 'arg1', 'arg2', and 'arg3' - and the range
for those integer arguments are supposed to each be zero to one thousand
inclusive. If I were to test this method, I would probably start with the
following simple bounds test data for each argument:

-1, 0, 999, 1000, 1001

I would then expand that to include -999, -1000, -1001 just to make sure
there wasn't some signage problem. Then I would include some magic numbers
such as 255 and 256 to test variable sizes (not as applicable to Java as
other languages, but what the hell).

Pretty basic testing theory right? Okay, here comes my point; what I would
not do is use every single data point between zero and one thousand, such as
1, 2, 3, 4, ... 1000. That would be inefficient and most likely ineffective.
Sure you could easily test each data point for a single argument with a
little bit of logic in the test code, but given that you have three
arguments, there would be one billion combinations of all positive integers.
Assuming you could run one thousand tests per second, it would take almost
twelve days to run through the positive combinations alone.

I am sure you have all heard of similar examples, but on a more abstract
level the same principle applies; the goal of testing is to find bugs, not
to test every possible combination of data. In most testing/QA efforts I
have been involved in, both as a QA Engineer and as a developer, we
carefully chose our test data, secnarios, suites, what have you, based on
what was most likely to find a bug. We also concentrated on those areas of
code that we had good reason to believe were the least robust, least tested
and the newest - i.e., for whatever reason had the most risk of being buggy.
Also, depending on the nature of the code and or product, we also may have
concentrated on code that, if it failed, would cause the most harm - e.g., I
worked for a company that used software to collect and analyze data from HIV
blood assays. In that case we were much less concerned about whether the
software crashed, or was user friendly, and much more concerned that the
data it generated, displayed, analyzed and stored was always correct. Lives
may have depended on correct data operations.

Each software product is different with regard to the various factors that
affect how testing is performed, but the things they all have in common are:

1) You can't test everything, so you have to concentrate one the testing
methodologies that are most likely to find bugs.

2) The earlier you test, the less costly and more effective/efficient it is
to find a bug.

So yes, you can "test too much" if the testing you are doing is ineffective,
inefficient and is not finding bugs - because it will take away time and
effort from more productive testing methodologies. There are various metrics
you can use to guesstimate the points where you may just be wasting time and
effort to test further, but you have to start your tests with well known
basics and work from there, and you should test early.

FWIW,
Lauren
